awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Improved Algorithms for Multiwave Imaging in Complex Media:  Theory and Computation
awd_abstract_narration:
Improved imaging techniques are necessary to guide and inform increasingly complex surgical procedures.  For example, cardiac bypass surgeries are required for infants born with congenital heart defects; however, approximately 50% of children develop brain injury perioperatively, leading to the damaging complications for survivors of congenital heart disease. Improved cerebral imaging techniques are needed to evaluate the effects of surgical procedures on brain perfusion. One of the most promising techniques for cerebral imaging are multiwave imaging methods such as photo-acoustic and thermo-acoustic tomography, which combine properties of different waves to obtain high contrast and resolution unattainable by traditional modalities.  This project is motivated by the possible application of multiwave imaging to monitor cerebral blood perfusion in infants. It aims to incorporate the complexity of media properties in the head (brain, vasculature, blood, cerebrospinal fluid, skull, skin) into these imaging techniques, while making these techniques more robust to noise and uncertainty. 

The goals of this project are both theoretical and computational. The first is to identify general assumptions under which the photo-acoustic measurements render the simultaneous recovery of the internal source and the wave speed. This will be accomplished by expanding the mathematical theory concerning the simultaneous recovery of acoustic sources and media properties, which is one of the main open questions regarding photo-, thermo- and magneto- acoustic imaging. Based on preliminary work, the investigators have relaxed a-priori conditions under which simultaneous recovery is possible. The next step is to determine which conditions are essential and which ones can be removed. The second goal is computational and uses the intrinsic property of the photo-acoustic effect, which produces high contrast pressure profiles. The aim is to design novel discontinuous Galerkin methods for accurate, low dispersion simulations of high contrast pressure waves for use in new imaging algorithms. These methods are designed to achieve high performance on GPU architectures in the presence of realistic media and geometries. The third goal is to incorporate these new developments into PDE-constrained optimization algorithms, which, in addition to approximating the unknown wave speed of the medium, will also provide robustness with respect to noise and lack of information.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated new algorithms for the numerical simulations of waves. These simulations serve as computational models for wave motion in many different types of materials (such as water, air, earth, or even bone and tissue) as well as different types of wave physics (e.g., acoustics, electromagnetic). Efficient and realistic simulations are important not only for the study of wave phenomena, but also for a variety of imaging techniques in different fields (e.g., seismic imaging in geophysics or ultrasound in medicine). For example, many imaging techniques use algorithms based on an advanced version of "guess and check" to gradually improve the quality of a reconstructed image. The results from computational simulations are used both to "check" a reconstructed image and to refine the quality of the reconstruction.

This project specifically focuses on numerical simulations of wave propagation applicable to the human body. Because waves propagate differently in different media (such as bone vs tissue), the numerical model must be able to accurately incorporate changes in media into computational simulations. Moreover, due to changes in wavelength with different types of media, the computational resolution required to accurately resolve waves can vary in different parts of the body. This necessitate numerical methods and computational algorithms which can resolve both sharp and gradual changes in media and resolution while retaining efficiency, and the focus of this project was the development of such methods.

This project introduced several new innovations in computational simulations of waves based on a technique recently invented by the PI. This technique introduced a highly accurate approximation within a computational algorithm (swapping out a weighted mass matrix by a "weight-adjusted" mass matrix) which significantly simplify a key step (a matrix inversion) while retaining accuracy and reliability. This change had several broader consequences. Because this step was made much simpler, we were able to create highly optimized specialized implementations on modern parallel computing architectures such as many-core CPUs and Graphics Processing Units (GPUs). This more efficient implementation also enabled the construction of numerical methods based on alternative mathematical representations of the equations which govern wave physics, which extended the range of physical settings in which one could reliably, accurately, and efficiently simulate wave propagation. Finally, these new computational simulations were also applied to solve inverse problems in photo-acoustic tomography, a new high-contrast imaging technique.

This award has supported two PhD students, and has also provided the PI with opportunities for outreach both at Rice University and within the greater Houston area. The PI provided mentoring to several undergraduates through research projects, and was a guest lecturer for Houston-area K-12 teachers. The project also resulted in several discoveries not directly related to wave phenomena. For example, the PI was able to develop a new class of simulation methods for high speed fluid flows which significantly improve the reliability of simulations based on high order approximations and unstructured meshes. These are promising technologies which have not yet been adopted by industry for various reasons, including issues of reliability.
